items.content:
#â€‹592 â€” May 10, 2023 | Read on the web

Using the Web Vitals Extension to Debug Core Web VitalsÂ Issues â€” The Web Vitals extension (for Chrome) now shows more debugging information to help you identify the root causes of Core Web Vitals issues. Even if you donâ€™t prefer Chrome as your day to day browser, these are handy tools when debugging Web performanceÂ issues.

Google Chrome Team

âš¡ï¸ The Chrome team has been on a bit of a performance blogging surge this week, with helpful articles on how large DOM sizes affect interactivity and finding data on slow interactions in field data. These are part of a broader suite of How to Optimize Interaction to Next Paint articles.

Cut Development Time in Half â€” Spend more time building and less on maintenance with Storyblok CMS: All your assets in one place, reusable components, and a simple visual editor so marketing/design/other teams can do things without buggingÂ you.

Storyblok sponsor

The Ongoing Defence of Frontend as a Full-Time Job â€” The author has worked at Microsoft, Mozilla, and Yahoo so he knows his stuff when it comes to the frontend. Heâ€™s now looking for a new job but experiencing friction over being â€œjustâ€ a frontend developer when, really, itâ€™s as important a discipline asÂ any.

Christian Heilmann

â–¶Â Â I'm Done with React â€” Going from least-to-most important, the reasons this developer isnâ€™t choosing React for future projects make for interesting watching, particularly if you too are overwhelmed by upheaval in the React world. Solid is one of the alternatives he has warmedÂ to.

Adam Elmore

Qwik Reaches v1.0 â€” In â€œother big JS frameworks that arenâ€™t Reactâ€, Qwik has hit a major milestone. Qwikâ€™s big selling point remains performance through serving up as little JavaScript as is needed on initial page loads. â€œThink of it as streaming for your JavaScript,â€ they say. Nonetheless, you get the JSX, directory-based routing, and middleware options you may be familiar withÂ elsewhere.

Qwik Team

âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF

  • React has unveiled a new 'canary' release channel to let users try out new features more quickly on an officially supported release.

  • Firefox 113 has been officially released. The 'picture in picture' feature gets improved, as does the support for AV1 and CSS Color Level 4, plus a 13 year feature request is in: accepting dragged and dropped files from Microsoft Outlook! You can also now override JavaScript files in the debugger.

  • The WebKit project has unveiled a new WebKit documentation site at docs.webkit.org.

  • I can't put my finger on why, but this HTML 'cheat sheet' page just overwhelmed me with a sense of nostalgia and intensity.

  • It's slight but the latest StatCounter browser market share stats show Chrome slightly down and Safari slightly up after being particularly static over the past year.

  • See this page fetch itself, byte by byte, over TLS.
